review.title: Complexity Analysis and Variational Inference for Interpretation-based Probabilistic Description Logic
review.abstract: This paper presents complexity analysis and variational methods for inference in probabilistic description logics featuring Boolean operators, quantification, qualified number restrictions, nominals, inverse roles and role hierarchies. Inference is shown to be PEXP-complete, and variational methods are designed so as to exploit logical inference whenever possible.

metadata.title: Complexity Analysis and Variational Inference for Interpretation-based Probabilistic Description Logics

sections.text: This paper presents complexity analyses and methods of variation for conclusions in probable description logic using Boolean operators, quantification, constraints of qualified numbers, nomenclatures, inverse roles and role hierarchies. Conclusions are presented as PEXP-complete, and methods of variation are designed to exploit logical conclusions whenever possible.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In this paper, we examine probable description logic based on the well-known descriptions logicALC = C. In ALC, we deal with individuals, concepts, roles, Boolean operators, and limited forms of quantification [1]. For example, the concept Fireman refers to the amount of firefighters and vegetarians u-buyFrom.Fireman refers to a set of individuals who are vegetarian and are purchased only by firefighters. We can also have assertions such as Fireman (John) stating that John belongs to Fireman. We start with credalALC, a probable description logic we introduced earlier [8, 33].Credal ALC, referring to CRALC, mixes constructs of ALC with features of relational Bayesian networks. In fact, most of this work can be read as a study of these relational Bayesian networks that can be expressed with (variants) of ALC.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: Using novel complexity analyses and algorithms, this paper has contributed to the conclusion in a family of probabilistic description logic with interpretation-based semantics and assumptions of cyclicity and independence. Variants of Proposition 1 and Theorem 1 should be applied to other first-order relational / probabilistic models [16, 34]; we note that there are currently relatively few results on complexity for these models. In addition, our analysis produces a meaningful class of PEXP-complete problems that may be useful for other applications.With regard to algorithms, the contributions here revolve around a variation scheme that essentially splits the disrupted network into smaller units in order to apply logical conclusions whenever possible. This idea should be useful for other probabilistic logic. Experiments show that our techniques are better than existing and can handle problems of practical importance, and the method can be adapted to handle infinite and unlimited domains, as well as situations in which uniformity is violated.
